posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
We’re trying to signal an Arduino to blink some lied using a DIO port on the Rio and are noticing… Strange behavior.  I stuck an oscilloscope on the output and noticed a spike when the output was supposed to go high, but it fell off quickly.  The curve looked, about, like a capacitor discharging.

So, just to eliminate possibilities… Are any other teams successfully using digital (not pwm) output on the Rio this year.

posts.name: Justin Sommer
posts.cooked: Yes, my team is using the DIO ports to control a RGB LED strip. It sounds like this could maybe be a software issue? It should, from my understanding, output a 0-5V output over the signal pin (not the middle pin) that should have a consistent voltage. The only time this wouldn’t be consistent is if the roboRIO is booting.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
Ok.  Thanks.  Just checking because it’s a relatively unused feature and I thought it could be a problem in this year’s FPGA or something.

Edit:

(1) Helps if I don’t have the oscope filter dc signals (2) Our problem was driving the Arduino with a USB power pack.  The Arduino didn’t draw enough current and the battery pack would shut off.
Why are you using Dio + Arduino as an intermediary for leds? Did you use up all 20 pwm ports on the Rio?

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: Bit of a digression, but can the Roborio PWM control an LED while disabled? That’s a limitation we found with the Blinkin, but there may be a way around it.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
nope. pwm used to be the only way to control motor controllers, and since those motor controllers are still legal, pwm is still only allowed to operate when the robot is enabled. (AFAIK)

a possible workaround is to have some kind of microcontroller that takes the blinkin pwm from the roborio, as well as some other output, maybe RS232 but i have no idea which work during disabled. when pwm is active, it forwards it but otherwise it makes its decision based on the secondary output.

me personally, im waiting for PoE led but thats a whole different level

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
ours defaults to what we manually set the blinkin to. am i missing something?

edit: its probably because we define it as a Spark motor controller. if its normal pwm (as in edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.PWM ), will it work even in disabled?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
A PWM output controlling a Blinkin is a normal PWM signal and thus it will be disabled when the robot is disabled.

Using a PWM port to directly control WS2812 LEDs using the AddressableLED class is not a PWM signal at all–it just uses that physical port–and thus is not disabled when the robot is disabled.

link_counts.title: Addressable LEDs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
Vasista:

Why are you using Dio + Arduino as an intermediary for leds?

Our initial LED code on the Rio crashed, and we had more important things to do.  This let us deal with LEDs off the Rio and just use a single GPIO call.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: interesting, will look into. i guess that makes blinkin a pointless hardware implementation of a software feature because its just a library of rgbw effects

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Well, the Blinken controls non-addressable LEDs too (eg where you just have R.G,B applied voltage to set the color of the whole strip), which the Rio can’t do directly.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
couldnt that work with 3 relay pins?

edit: no precise colors with this. i need to think a little harder

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: You wouldn’t want to use relays, those are either full on or full off.  You’d want to use power MOSFETs controlled by a DIO output in duty cycle output mode.  But again, whole strip and external components required.  AddressableLED needs only the RIO.  All of these options of course also need a voltage regulator big enough to power the strip.
